Class BrickWall

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  BrickWall
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class BrickWall
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.io.Serializable

A component for playing Brickles, which is a game where a ball bounces around a playing area, knocking out bricks in a wall.

The sides of the game area are each either bounded by a solid wall or guarded by a bat whose position is controlled by the mouse. So long as the ball rebounds off a wall or is hit by the bat, it remains in play. When it misses a bat, the ball stops and its position is reset.

The ball continues to move so long as the mouse button is pressed and held in the game area. Releasing the mouse causes the game to pause; pressing again resumes the movement from the same position.

The wall contains a specified number of rows and columns. Individual bricks are specified by row and column number, with rows and columns numbered from 1.

Semantic events about the ball's collisions are reported as CollisionEvents through the CollisionListener interface. Collisions can be reported with bricks, walls, and bats. In addition, the special "collision" type "miss" indicates that the ball has passed a bat, and "none" indicates that the ball has moved without colliding with anything.

See Also:
CollisionEvent, CollisionListener, Serialized Form

buildWall

public void buildWall(int firstRow,
                      int lastRow,
                      int firstColumn,
                      int lastColumn,
                      java.awt.Color brickColor)
Builds a wall of bricks of the specified color. A null color causes bricks to be removed. Row and column values outside the allowable range have no effect on the wall.

Parameters:
firstRow - the first row to build
lastRow - the last row to build
firstColumn - the first column to build
lastColumn - the last column to build
brickColor - the color of the bricks

setBrick

public void setBrick(int row,
                     int column,
                     java.awt.Color brick)
Sets the brick at a specified row and column to the specified color. Setting the color to null removes the brick. If row or column are outside the allowable range, no change is made to the wall.

Parameters:
row - the row of the brick
column - the column of the brick
brick - the color of the brick

setWalls

public void setWalls(boolean north,
                     boolean south,
                     boolean east,
                     boolean west,
                     int size,
                     java.awt.Color color)
Sets the properties of the walls.

The boolean parameters determine which sides are bounded by solid walls. If a wall is not present, that side is guarded by a bat. The default setting has walls on all sides except south.

Size determines the thickness of the walls as a percentage of the length of the shortest wall. For example a size of 2 when the component is 400 x 500 pixels specifies a wall thickness of 8 pixels (2% of 400). If the size is 0, the walls are not visible (but balls will still bounce off them). The default size is 2.

Color determines the color of the walls. A color of null specifies that the walls should be drawn in foreground color. The default color is null.

Parameters:
north - if true the north side has a wall
south - if true the south side has a wall
east - if true the east side has a wall
west - if true the west side has a wall
size - the wall size
color - the wall color

setBat

public void setBat(int size,
                   int bevel,
                   java.awt.Color color)
Sets the properties of the bats.

Size is specified as a percentage of the length of the shortest wall. For example a size of 10 when the component is 400 x 500 pixels specifies a bat that is 40 pixels (10% of 400). The default size is 20.

Bevel specifies the angle of reflection in degrees for balls that strike the outer thirds of the bats. For example a bevel angle of 10 means that balls striking the outer edges are deflected by an additional 10 degrees. The default bevel angle is 5.

Color specifies the color of the bats. A color of null specifies that the bat should be drawn in the foreground color. The default color is null.

Parameters:
size - the bat size
bevel - the bat bevel angle
color - the bat color

setBall

public void setBall(int speed,
                    int smoothness,
                    int size,
                    java.awt.Color color)
Sets the properties of the ball.

Speed is expressed as the number of times in 10 seconds that the ball could travel the entire width or height of the BrickWall and return to its starting point. For example, a ball speed of 5 would mean that the ball could make 5 round trips in 10 seconds. If the speed is set to 0, the ball is stopped. The default speed is 3.

Smoothness is expressed as the number of animation frames for the ball to move a distance equal to the size of a brick. For example, a smoothness of 4 means that the ball moves one quarter of the size of a brick between animation frames. Larger values make the movement look smoother, but require faster redraw rates that may exceed the capacity of the system. Values less than 1 are invalid. The default value is 4.

Size is specified as a percentage of the length of the shortest wall. For example a size of 3 when the component is 400 x 500 pixels specifies a ball that is 12 pixels (3% of 400). The default size is 3.

Color specifies the color of the ball. A color of null specifies that the ball should be drawn in foreground color. The default color is null.

Parameters:
speed - the ball speed
smoothness - the ball smoothness
size - the ball size
color - the ball color

setBallReset

public void setBallReset(int row,
                         int column,
                         int heading)
Sets the "reset" ball position and heading (the state of the ball following a miss). Position is specified by row number and column number. Heading is specified as a compass direction, where 0 is northwards, 90 is eastwards, and so on. The default reset position is the middle column of the second-bottom row, heading 15 degrees east of north.

Parameters:
row - the row number
column - the column number
heading - the heading

setReportMask

public void setReportMask(int mask)
Sets the mask used to determine which collisions are reported. The mask comprises separate bits for each possible collision type, as specified by CollisionEvent. Multiple collision types can be reported by ORing more than one event type. For example if the mask is CollisionEvent.BRICK|CollisionEvent.MISS, collisions with bricks and missed balls are be reported. The default report mask is CollisionEvent.BRICK

Parameters:
mask - the report mask

getReportMask

public int getReportMask()
Gets the reportMask.

Returns:
the report mask
